To get on the same page, you are suggesting cancel culture is a tool used by the people to go after injustices they may not otherwise be able to. I don't take issue with that, people should face consequences when they're being amoral. My personal issue with cancel culture is how egregious offences and minor mistakes lead to the same outcomes. My perspective is a lot of innocent people were caught in the crossfire. People who said terrible things online weren't punished enough in the eyes of many online and it felt to me that others were unfairly prosecuted because they were lumped in with the rest. The sought after outcome I remember from when cancel culture was prevalent was the person being cancelled losing their job or livelihood, which makes sense in some cases, but in others it seemed very unfair. I believe this is why we don't see the same effects of cancel culture nowadays, as people saw injustice in how it was administered and no longer felt comfortable participating.

I notice that you mention equality and I agree: equality is important. But the point that needs to be made is that current political and social injustices call for equity, not equality. By fighting for equality in the argument of abortion, you are valuing an unborn fetus at the same degree to which you value an already existing, living, born mother. By shifting your mindset to focusing on equity, you can rewrite the narrative and focus on more vulnerable populations that require our attention now. Although I do value your points that people can be irresponsible in conceiving a baby, we should take more care of the people who exist now–not the people who don't exist yet.

The right to decide what happens to your body also includes the decision to use birth control or abstain from unprotected sex. Conservatives are not jeopardizing the lives of women, liberals are bypassing the rights of unborn children and more than simply jeopardizing their lives but entirely ending the lives of the next generation out of a selfish desire to have a complication-free life.

There is a lot of misrepresentation surrounding the issue of abortion. The vast majority of abortions take place early on in the pregnancy because the person didn't want to be pregnant in the first place. Very rarely do people actually go into the process simply for convenience. And later term abortions happen rarely, but when they do, it is almost always to protect the life of the mother or because the baby will not survive after birth for very long, so it is seen as a way to avoid suffering. Anyone who has an issue with people getting abortions early in the pregnancy should support childcare measures that might incentivize people to go through with the pregnancy because they'll be more equipped to support the child.

I agree with the data presented, but I believe there is more data to add here. Yes, China and India are polluting much more than America, but does that mean we should not still help our environment? I think there is a balance here between jobs and helping the environment; in other words, I believe we can cut down on major polluters while maintaining jobs. In regards to science, there is no doubt that it is not always correct. However, I'd like to think about the environment in another way, in terms of our health as people. Pollution is terrible for human health and could be the causes of major diseases, such as cancer. For our own health, saving our environment is beneficial.

You've made a strong case for why "cancel culture" can be seen as a form of accountability rather than mere censorship. You highlight that it's often marginalized groups holding those in power accountable for their actions and speaking out against various forms of injustice. While it’s true that some reactions in this realm can be extreme or misdirected, the broader goal is to foster a more just society by addressing harmful behaviors and holding individuals accountable. The challenge lies in balancing the pursuit of justice with fairness and ensuring that calls for accountability don’t inadvertently silence important dialogue or lead to unintended consequences.

I think you're right that Republicans often misconstrue elements of call-out culture, lumping clearly immoral behavior (e.g., Alex Jones on Sandy Hook) into this idea that people who are "just exercising their first-amendment right" are being "canceled" by the internet mob.
Like many polarized issues, however, I think it's important to consider where the other side may have a point. There are also examples of individuals losing their platforms over a misunderstanding. Clips can now be taken out of context (for example, a streamer who says "I used to like children romantically...when I was a child"), accounts get hacked, and AI-created videos and voice clips are getting more convincing. Additionally, there is even research showing that students on campus and public figures feel less comfortable even talking about sensitive topics that might get them "canceled." It may be that most of the people who we call out for bad behavior online or in the world genuinely deserve it, but I haven't seen much discussion about the issue of false-positives or how to create an environment that is friendly to discussion, even when that might be offensive.

I think there are some valid concerns you've raised, but I fear you're speaking with too big a brush. First of all, China and India, each, have something like 3x our population, don't they? So individually, they would be expected to pollute more than us. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't cut back; they should also cut back. It is certainly terrible to have working class people in traditional energy industries lose their jobs, but that's something we can work towards fixing too. Don't we need lots of jobs to make the stuff that uses wind and solar power? We could incentivize plants for those things in areas that are currently coal mining, oil drilling, etc.

I am not very persuaded by this definition. I would disagree that cancel culture is when "minorities, marginalized groups, and victims stick up for themselves and speak their truth." I interpret cancel culture as something closed-minded people do when they disagree with someone else's opinion and are incapable of having a respectful discussion. People have a freedom to speak their mind and we must respect and tolerate all points of view, even when we disagree with them. If people are being intentionally hateful, we should not encourage that bad behavior obviously. We should educate them on why what they are saying is hurtful. However, cancel culture today is often a tactic from the Left to silence people they disagree with. I was someone who was on the receiving end of cancel culture simply for being a conservative and supporting conservative policies. During 2020, people from my school were "outing" all conservatives and were encouraging others to harass us. Getting cancelled for my political identity is not right, and that is where we are seeing most of cancel culture today. I agree that people should not be allowed to get away with racism, misogyny, exploitation, or abuse, and there needs to be consequences for their actions. However, it seems like the left uses cancel culture as a form of character assassination or as a political weapon to shut down any opposition.

I think that some good points of discussion are brought up, but I feel there are a few that are missing. Yes, abortions can occur for financial reasons or if their is a risk of health complications (of the child) or disbility. Other reasons include health complications of the women giving birth and the potential birth of a child born from rape. If going through pregnancy presents potentially fatal health risks, a women should have a choice of abortion. If a women becomes pregnant through rape, she should not be forced to have the child. Furthermore, the government determining if a women can have an abortion seems like a set too far in regards to legislature. If the government can deny a women autonomy over her body what else can they deny her and citizens? It is also important to make a distinction between abortions and late-term abortions (before and after a heartbeat has been discovered). If their is no heartbeat, it is not human life. Late-term abortions are another topic of discussion that most likely does require government intervention.
Finally, having a choice is important. Abortion being legal does not mean everyone will have an abortion, it just means it is an option. This would not force those who are against abortion to have have them. However, making abortion illegal would restrict those who in favor of it to have them. Lastly, in addition to this making abortions illegal would not prevent them. It means that people will go to greater lengths to have these procedures done "under the table" potentially by those who are not medical professional which would be dangerous.

I understand and agree with your point that forcing an end to an innocent, unborn, living human beings is a cruel thing to do. Unfortunately, we don't live in a perfect world. Abortions are results are people making poor decisions that they regret later (such as having unprotected intercourse), but they are also results of people being harmed by others (such as having nonconsensual intercourse). It's rather hard for us to overlook these issues, and banning abortion as a whole would not: (1) force people to have unprotected intercourse (there will always be people making poor decisions), and (2) prevent nonconsensual intercourse. In fact, banning abortion would actually increase the rate of harmful, illegal practices of abortion, because people will always find ways to get away. Additionally, we need to consider others' difficult circumstances (and brainstorm what better we can do, such as expanding sex education, or setting more strict laws against rape) rather than take their rights away.

I understand that abortion is a deeply emotional and complex issue for many people. However, I believe it’s important to recognize that the debate isn’t limited to one political party. People from various political backgrounds, including Republicans, Democrats, and independents, have diverse views on this topic.

It’s also worth noting that the reasons behind seeking an abortion are often multifaceted and deeply personal. While some may view it as a matter of convenience, others see it as a necessary decision for their health, well-being, or due to circumstances beyond their control.

Ultimately, I think it’s crucial to approach this conversation with empathy and an open mind, acknowledging that there are valid concerns and perspectives on all sides. Dictating to a woman what she can and cannot do with her body, in my opinion, is unjust. There are plenty of people who agree and disagree with your thought process, but the end result is still an issue for all and lets take into account the women who has not only physically go through this but mentally as well. At the end of the day, to me, there is a litany of scientific literature saying that climate change is occurring and will be a detriment to society that I believe it is a priority to solve it. Besides, coal and gas are a nonrenewable resource anyways and have well studied negative affects beyond climate change, (air pollution, water pollution, environmental effects from extraction and transport) that I think are much less well pronounced in other green options.

While other countries might be contributing negatively to the environment, that does not negate our negative effect and our need to do better. If people waited we would get to a point of no return. There is no certainty when estimating that is why it is an estimate. The coastal cities might not be underwater right now due to the progress we are making to reduce our carbon footprint. Just because it is not someone's fault is not a reason to keep jobs that are hurting the environment or the future. We need to keep evolving and improving as more information becomes available instead of being stagnant with energy that will be completely phased out in the next 20 years. Everything is cyclical.

It sounds like your issue with abortions is the safety and civil rights of the mother/woman involved. If you were to ban abortions some women would choose to have an unsafe one, and that it takes women's freedom away. I can understand both of these concerns, however I have a different perspective. If the unborn child is defined as a human being with human rights, then their rights must be considered in medical situations and protected by the government. In the same way that we have an obligation to protect a child being abused by their parents, we must protect the unborn child to not be aborted for convenience. The government and the people have an obligation to protect human rights and life, especially when the party cannot defend themselves. I think that an unborn child is alive and has human rights, so we as a society are obligated for that protection.

I agree that people in politics use hot-topic issues as a way to gain power and persuade people to be on their side. Although environmental health is important, many of the ways that are being proposed to save the environment are actually hurting it. For instance, electric cars use lithium batteries, which currently have no way of being safely disposed of or recycled. The radiation these batteries emit is detrimental to human and natural life, so the fight for carbon neutral/EV cars is faulty. Instead of using hot-topic issues as a way to gain support and following, politicians need to pursue topics they actually care about tackling themselves; not topics the public wants them to take on. This will lead to more authentic politicians, politicians following through with their word and campaign goals, and issues actually being acted on and solved (since there is passion in the topic by the person trying to solve the issue).

It’s important to approach discussions about abortion with empathy and a deep understanding of the diverse factors that individuals face. While you’ve framed abortion as a civil rights issue centered on the rights of the unborn, it’s crucial to consider the broader context of personal autonomy and societal impacts.  The right to choose an abortion is fundamentally about respecting personal autonomy. Every individual has the right to make decisions about their own body and life circumstances. This decision often involves complex, deeply personal factors such as health risks, financial stability, and readiness to parent. The ability to make this choice is not about valuing convenience over human life but rather about ensuring that individuals have the agency to make informed decisions based on their unique situations.  Legal access to abortion is a critical aspect of maintaining health and safety. When abortion services are restricted or illegal, it doesn’t eliminate the need but rather drives individuals to seek unsafe, potentially life-threatening alternatives. Ensuring access to safe, regulated abortions protects individuals from dangerous procedures and aligns with a commitment to their well-being.

Abortion is one of the biggest concerns regarding civil rights in our time. However, it is important to note the stages of life these "living human beings" are at when they are being quote unquote "slaughtered". It is also important to recognize that Democrats do not willingly support murder-- regardless of how the media casts it. Generally, people do not solely abort a baby due to financial hardships, there are other factors involved, such as age, maturity, situational hardships such as rape, incest, and support. I am a firm believer that after a certain period in a pregnancy, when the embryo is starting to be fully developed and turned into a baby, people should consider choices with their provided medical professionals. However, I would argue that it is just as unethical to force an 8-year old girl to birth a baby because in that case, if you are arguing "pro-life", you are disregarding the 8-year old's health, bodily functions, and life. You cannot argue for pro-life if you are willing to harm a fully existing person.

It seems that you disagree with the way you think the liberal party has decided to address climate change and environmental well being, which you thought was by shutting down traditional energy industries that result in job loss. It also seems that you believe the US is not at fault for environmental warming and should therefore not partake in solutions. However, The leading CO2 emissions are actually from China and the United States, with India emitting 2 tons of CO2 less than the United States, so I think pollution is our problem that we have contributed to. Additionally, there is scientific evidence that has tracked the average temperature in different regions across decades, and statistical differences have been noted. Sea levels are in fact rising, and more natural disasters are occurring as a result of the global change in climate, so I believe that we do have an idea of how much the environment is changing. I'm not too familiar with the actual approach liberals are taking to mitigate the United States' contribution to environmental warming, but as some jobs close, others will open as we switch from one energy source to another. I think global warming is a serious problem that every human being has contributed to (using cars, using plastics, using aerosols, even breathing produces CO2), and we must all do our part to save the planet that we collectively live on, or else there will be no habitable parts of earth left for the future generations and these conversations will have been for nothing.

In my opinion your views are wrong based on existing evidence. The idea that coastal cities would be underwater was an outdated scientific statement that seemed factual back in the 1970s and has evolved constantly throughout the years based on tangible evidence we have for global warming. China and India pollute more than us because they produce products that we buy, meaning that their pollution rates are directly correlated to our demand. And in the face of traditional energy industries dying out, working class people have an opportunity to take advantage of a growing renewable energy market. With more investments and manpower, industries like wind and solar can become the dominant force in America and no job loss needs to occur.

Abortion is a way for people to prioritize their health and abilities.  If someone is pregnant but cannot support the child, is at risk of losing their own life, or has some other reason that is personal, abortion should be an option that is available to them.  Additionally, most people do not have an abortion because of cost or disabilities.  Most people have abortions because of extenuating circumstances, such as rape or incest, and in cases where the life of the person giving birth is threatened. Moreover, it is not about the act of abortion in and of itself, but it is more about the choice that should be available to people to decide whether or not to have an abortion. It is ok to have different perspectives on the topic, but that does not mean that outside forces should be determining what someone can or cannot do with their body.

I think it is important to think about the living human beings in these situations as well, women or sometimes girls, are put into these impossible situations where they have to choose their own future or some unknown future that may have not ever have been an option for them it may have just been forced upon them. And when these people don't have a way to support those children it should also be considered. There are so many children living in poverty who have parents who can't feed them or provide support and that isn't any better. We only talk about the birth of these children and not supporting them after they are born. If we are going to take away women's ability to seek out abortions then we need to be providing alternatives so they do not find themselves in that situation including but not limited to: informed sex education, free and affordable birth control, affordable child care, affordable housing, safety in schools, etc.

Certain people being willing to perform abortions for potentially unfair or inequitable reasons does not mean that abortion as a whole is an unfair or unjust practice. Portraying those who choose to abort their pregnancies as choosing convenience over human life is disingenous--oftentimes, the life the mother is saving is their own, as giving birth may cause an undue burden upon her or her family. Especially in the current economic climate, it would not be fair to raise a child in an environment where the mother and family is unprepared or unwilling to support it properly is much more damaging. Furthermore, portraying abortion as something only supported and carried out by Democrats is unfair. I am sure many non-Democrats and Republicans have at one point or another needed access to abortion, and stating that the Democrats "don't seem to care" does not account for the fact that the Democrat's position approaches the value of human life from a different angle.

Convenience is not the biggest issue for most decent human beings. More often, people who get abortions are concerned about a lack of safety for themselves or the child if it were born. They may live in abusive households or be homeless or simply too unstable to support another human life. There are also such things as endometrial pregnancies in which the mother could die. In cases such as rape as well, the mother may be too traumatized to properly care for the baby. Furthermore, adoption and foster care systems can be incredibly corrupt and dangerous so some people assume that abortion would be a more merciful option. I agree that abortion is incredibly awful and should be used as a last resort, but the current political state of America is unable to give mothers who might need an abortion another choice.

Just because other countries are polluting more than us doesn't mean that we shouldn't strive to make the world cleaner. Most carbon emissions in the US are produced by large corporations, and more notable, the meat industry. People should not be losing jobs because of these changes, and if they are, it is the fault of these corporations for firing people to reduce costs instead of making changes that benefit the average citizen, and the environment.

Thank you for sharing your perspective. It sounds like you’re concerned that the environmental movement might be driven more by political motives than by genuine concern for the planet. I also hear that you're worried about the impact that environmental policies could have on working-class families, particularly those in traditional energy industries, and you feel that the burden of addressing climate change might be unfairly placed on Americans while other countries like China and India are bigger contributors to pollution.

I agree that it's important to consider the economic effects of environmental policies, especially on those whose livelihoods are directly affected. The transition to cleaner energy should definitely account for job losses and provide solutions for workers in these industries. I also understand your skepticism about the scientific consensus, and it’s true that past predictions can sometimes seem exaggerated or inaccurate, which can lead to frustration and doubt.

That said, I think the focus might be less about blame and more about what each country, including the U.S., can do to contribute to a global solution. While China and India are large polluters, many experts believe that every country has a role to play in reducing emissions, and the U.S., as a major economy, can lead by example in innovation and clean energy.

Ultimately, I think there’s a lot of room for us to discuss how we can protect both jobs and the environment, and I’d be interested to hear more about your thoughts on what solutions could strike a better balance.

People who support abortion don't support it because they don't care; rather, they support it because they do care. Children whose families cannot afford to take care of them or who have a disability have a much higher chance of being put up for adoption, neglected, or abused. The foster care system in our country is overwhelmed and underfunded. Banning abortion means that these children have a higher chance of suffering. Banning abortion means that women will seek much more dangerous ways to get an abortion. Banning abortion means women who need to get an abortion in cases such as rape or medical emergency cannot get one. Banning abortion means that women do not have a voice for their own body. Banning abortion is not "pro-life".

I think it's important to consider the reality of abortions in America. My understanding is that nobody is getting an abortion for any reason other than absolute necessity. Getting an abortion is not an easy decision, and it's not something people choose to do if they're able to avoid it. It's also important to consider that regardless of whether abortion is legal or not, people will try (likely in much more dangerous ways) to get abortions.

I agree with you that abortion is the biggest civil rights issue of our time. Personally, my stance on abortion is pro-life as in my opinion abortion includes other vulnerable populations including the parents of the child. I think that there are various factors to take into consideration when discussing abortion including, the socioeconomic and environmental status of the parent (and soon to be child), the quality of the United States foster care system and its long term impact on children, if the child was conceived by rape, the safety of the mother, and the safety and quality of life of the child regarding being born with a disability. It also seems to me that you have categorized all democrats into one group in which they do not care. Lastly, I know that it can be scary to think that all abortions will be legal, however, I believe that the majority of the laws surrounding abortion have strict guidelines that prevent unlawful, unsafe, and unethical abortions from being performed. I appreciate you sharing your passionate views on the topic.

While I hear your point and understand where you are coming from completely, I am a firm believer in people being held accountable for their actions and facing any consequences that are associated with them. I feel that most of the time, people who are claiming instances of harassment or assault are not lying, merely trying to share their trauma and make an unsafe person known to the public. I think it is the job of the people hearing these call-outs to make sure they are doing their due diligence to make sure that a conclusion isn't hasty and is based on understanding the whole situation. I also think that presentism plays a role in the conversation. Holding people in the past accountable to modern-day standards can create difficulty in bridging generational divides. I believe this is a nuanced issue and should be approached as such.

Thank you for sharing your perspective. I understand that this is a deeply emotional and complex issue for many people. I respect your concerns about the rights of unborn children and the value of human life.

At the same time, I believe it's important to consider that many people who support the right to choose do so not because they devalue life, but because they believe in the importance of bodily autonomy and in the right for individuals, particularly women, to make deeply personal decisions about their own health and future. For some, abortion is not about convenience, but about responding to circumstances that may be harmful to both the potential child and the person carrying the pregnancy, such as health risks, financial instability, or situations involving trauma.

In a society that values equality, we must also consider the living conditions into which children are born. Supporting reproductive rights, in my view, is not about devaluing life but about ensuring that every child brought into the world has the chance to thrive in a supportive and stable environment. At the same time, we can work to expand access to healthcare, education, and social services that help prevent unwanted pregnancies and support those who choose to carry pregnancies to term.

I believe we can find common ground in wanting to protect and uplift life, even if we have different ideas on how to achieve that.

I think that your viewpoint makes sense if we consider an unborn fetus a whole person. I was similarly frustrated before by the same issue. However, an unborn fetus, in my eyes, is not a person--which is why I believe abortion is acceptable. It is not part of the human moral community, it is not sentient, does not have emotion, self-awareness, or moral agency, and it cannot reason nor communicate. That is not to say that *all* of those are required to be a person, but it still does not satisfy any of those criteria. Additionally, I think we should not let the potential life of an unborn human trump the moral rights of an adult person.

I think quality of life is a big concern surrounding all issues, including abortion. It would be nice for every child to have a good life - that's what we hope for - but it's not always possible. Many people who have abortions are doing so for medical purposes and/or because they are too poor, too young, or too irresponsible/immature to have a child. There are also those who have an abortion because they did not consent to the child's conception. I think it's important to remember the reasons behind the majority of cases, rather than the edge cases, which can be more sensitive (aborting as a form of birth control or simply because they want to). There's also the potential mothers to consider in terms of quality of life. Should the needs of an unborn fetus supercede those of someone with consciousness and a full life already? That's a controversial question but I personally think not. I think personal freedom should be upheld in most situations, for example: abortion except for third trimester, guns except for the mentally ill and assault rifles, alcohol and marijuana except for while driving. To apply this philosophy evenly, I think it's important to uphold the potential mothers' rights. (They said they might contact me about this - please do not respond/contact me.)

Although China and India are highly responsible for pollution/greenhouse gas emissions, this does not negate the responsibility for the United States to limit their own contribution.  According to the Global Carbon Project, the U.S. remains one of the top emitters per capita, and thus, U.S. actions have a significant global impact and can set important precedents for other countries.

Just because coastal cities aren't "underwater" by now, there is indisputable proof that sea levels are rising.  If this isn't significant to you, there is proof that the climate is getting warmer, and a clearly defined connection between a warmer environment and extreme weather events.

Pertaining to jobs, investment into renewable energy could grow the economy, creating new jobs and economic opportunities while making the country cleaner/less polluted.  There are opportunities for workers in traditional energy industries to transition to these roles.

As someone who lies on the moderate-right side of the political spectrum, I support environmentalism to some extent; I don't want every forest in the world to be protected, but I don't believe the Amazon should be bulldozed to create factories.  I don't think oil should or could be completely eliminated by 2030, but I believe cleaner alternatives should be invested in to significantly reduce its use.  Changes like this are necessary to ensure the long-term viability of our planet (including humans).

While the issue of abortion is deeply complex and personal, supporting abortion rights is fundamentally about protecting the autonomy and equality of women. It's essential to recognize that making abortion illegal or inaccessible doesn't stop abortions; it only makes them unsafe. Access to safe and legal abortion allows women to make decisions about their own bodies and futures, especially in situations where continuing a pregnancy might be life-threatening, a result of violence, or unsustainable due to severe health issues or financial instability.

Supporting abortion rights is not about valuing convenience over life but about trusting individuals to make the best decisions for their circumstances. It also acknowledges the harsh realities that many women face, such as poverty, lack of healthcare, or social support, and the potential lifelong impact of being forced to carry an unwanted pregnancy to term. Ensuring access to abortion is part of a broader commitment to gender equality, allowing women to have the same freedom to control their lives and futures as men do. Democrats advocate for making abortion safe and legal because it upholds a woman's right to choose and ensures that all women, regardless of their circumstances, have access to the care they need.

I understand that you feel that the left is weaponizing the environment, but it's also critical to think about previous historical information. The ozone layer had a hole in the 1970's from CFCS (chlorofluorocarbons), commonly found in aerosols and other household products of the time. In 1985, the government adopted the Vienna Convention for the protection of the ozone layer. It seems that your primary concern is the loss of millions of jobs - if anything, the trades are consistently recruiting and are willing to train from the ground up. Having watched my own father make an industry change as well, I can say it can be difficult, but the overall quality of life as well as pay remains the same.

I understand that language can be hurtful and many of those who call out hurtful language or actions do so with good intentions. That being said, I think it has gotten out of hand. I do not believe that cancel culture should have the power to take movies off of screens, books off of shelves, music off of radios, and ruin people's careers. If you don't like a movie, don't watch it. It is that simple. The same goes for reading books, listening to songs, or anything else that these internet trolls go to far lengths to scrutinize. Just because a few people think too deeply into a source of entertainment, doesn't mean it should be taken away from those who like it. Likewise, I do not think that something someone said when they were a teenager should haunt them when they are a much more mature adult. People say dumb things; people also change over time with experience. I guarantee that you, like all 7.9 billion other people on earth, have said something you now look back on and realize was naive of you to say. That's all it is for everyone else, even public figures.

I appreciate you sharing your perspective on the environmental movement. It's clear that you're concerned about the potential economic impact, particularly on working-class communities in traditional energy sectors, and the effectiveness of environmental policies. These are important considerations, especially when jobs and livelihoods are at stake.

However, I’d like to offer a different view on some of the points you raised. While it’s true that countries like China and India are major polluters, the U.S. also has a significant impact on global emissions, and what we do can set a powerful example for the rest of the world. The argument that our actions won’t make a difference overlooks the potential for technological innovation and leadership that can drive global change. Moreover, addressing environmental issues isn't just about immediate effects but about ensuring a sustainable future for all, including the communities currently dependent on fossil fuels.

Regarding the scientific consensus, it’s important to note that climate predictions are complex and involve a range of scenarios. While some early predictions may not have played out exactly as expected, the overwhelming evidence still points to significant changes in our climate, with rising sea levels and more extreme weather patterns already affecting many areas. The focus should be on mitigating these risks before they become unmanageable.

Lastly, the transition to greener energy doesn’t have to be at the expense of working-class jobs. With the right policies, we can invest in retraining programs and create new, well-paying jobs in renewable energy sectors. It’s not about choosing between the environment and the economy, but about finding solutions that protect both. By working together, we can address climate change in a way that’s fair to everyone involved.

For that reason, I think that the question should not be based so much on the equality of all human beings, but rather on considering the counterfactuals that arise from aborting versus not aborting the child.

First, I encourage you to look at original sources when it comes to things like "Scientific consensus", because the idea that cities would all be underwater by now sounds like something that is distorted via media fear-mongering for clicks and ad-revenue. Some places, like Tuvalu, are having problems with rising sea levels, but it'll be a while until any US coastal cities have major issues (assuming we don't do anything to prevent or deal with that).

Second, China is investing heavily in renewable energy, so it's not just America working on these things. Personally, I'd rather have America leading the way on renewable energy manufacturing than China. Also, climate change isn't an all-or-nothing thing, so even if China wasn't working on renewable energy things would still improve some from America working on it.

Finally, renewable energy is getting cheaper and cheaper, so it is likely the future regardless of environmental concerns. Thus, it's important to help people who work in traditional energy sectors transition to jobs in renewable energy. I agree that it's not their fault that they will need to change jobs, but that's simply the way the world has always worked. You don't see many typewriter factories these days, but no one is fighting for people to not have computers and go back to typewriters because it was unfair computers made them lose their jobs. "The left" seems to be the only people recognizing this reality and trying to create new jobs for those workers.

I hear you. Your point highlights the fear you have surrounding your fellow Americans and their intentions with this form of health care. I'm not sure if I agree with the idea of indifference to human life, and I generally believe abortion is a scary concept. I do, however, see reproductive medical procedures as an individual decision. Unfortunately, some people have no choice but to go under the knife due to their respective medical needs or issues. Because of this, I am pro-choice; I have no desire to allow or disallow someone to go through with an invasive surgical procedure. I do believe this procedure is painful, and I am not convinced that anyone takes this issue lightly.

While it may be true that the U.S. pollutes less than China and India, the U.S. pollutes more per capita. The average American contributes more to pollution than the average Indian or Chinese. Even if China and India were polluting more per capita, it should not matter to us. We ought to do what is right, namely protect the environment, even if our peers are not. If we can set a positive example, it will make others more likely to follow. The cure is not worse than the disease if the disease disrupts future generations' way of life. I do not think the way forward is to immediately eliminate traditional energy industries. I believe in a shift towards green energy becoming our main source. This shift should include training and education, especially for working class folk, to better prepare them for employment in the green energy industry.

If you could spend a year in the countries that are the worst affected by climate change, you could understand how real the climate change is. As I grew up, I saw the changes in how heat waves killed many people, acid rains killed cattle, floods got worse, making people homeless, and food prices went higher due to limited land left for agriculture. Things were not like this before; natural calamities are happening much more frequently because of climate change. Those countries are doing more than the USA to check climate change by banning plastic use, using reusable materials, planting more trees, and using public and electric transport. The USA faces climate change impact to a lesser extent because its location is close to the North Pole, so the weather is not hotter in the summer months like other places on earth. 
Traditional energy jobs negatively impact the employees' health and the whole community where the raw materials are collected, as they leak into surrounding ground and water. Please rethink: Don't you want this world to be healthy for everyone? Don't you want this world to be a wonderful place for the next generation?

Even if other countries are polluting more than the US, what we do still makes a difference. We are one of the largest countries in the world and one of the top pollutors. To succeed, we have to improvise and adapt to whatever new technologies and trends come our way.

I think "call-out culture" is more than what your response reveals. I do not believe that the use of the term is restricted to Republicans or people in power. I think "call-out-culture" is when alleged victims advocating for themselves results in a hasty and unregulated "social punishment" enacted on the accused. This social punishment can range from negative press to defamation and can result in consequences such as termination from employment. While all victims deserve a voice and as much support as possible, I believe that "call-out culture" is not a good way to go about it. While it is very quick in enacting a form of justice, I believe that it opens the door to a "guilty until proven innocent" mentality, with the possibility of certain people using "call-out culture" for the wrong reasons (ex: to knowingly hurt others that are completely innocent).

The environment, our planet, is politically neutral in a wholly literal sense. It does not care about the political leanings of whoever is polluting it or working to clean it up; it will passively continue to spin through space long after we have nuked ourselves into oblivion, poisoned our oceans, run out of industrial resources, left for other planets, or otherwise managed to destroy our current Earth-bound societies.

If you have any amount of morals and forward planning skills, then you should be helping to protect the future by working to maintain a sustainable planet and industrial cycle so we as a species can survive here as long as possible; your political beliefs, nation, religion, etc. should not even be part of that consideration because they all do not matter in the face of mass extinction due to global failure to adapt and protect.

I agree that abortion is one of the most significant civil rights issues today. However, I disagree with the notion that it is exactly the same as murder. I truly believe there is something unique about the embryo or fetus that has implications regarding dignity and protection. While there is a potential human life inside, we must also consider the mother, a woman who has rights over her body. Simplifying abortion as murder alienates and polarizes, thereby limiting the possibility of a good-faith conversation. Furthermore, I agree with you on the importance of human life, but forcing women to have babies is likely the worst course of action if you genuinely care about children (and humans in general). Children deserve loving parents, not two people—often just the mother—who are forced to care for them because of state-imposed regulations. Lastly, I disagree with the negative portrayal of Democrats. It’s important to recognize that different perspectives on this issue exist. While this topic is obviously related to ideology and partisanship, focusing solely on those aspects limits the potential for consensus.

First, abortion is not limited to the Democratic party. Many people of all political affiliations have abortions, and it is not as black and white as you are making it out to be. More people than you realize have abortions because they are life-saving medical procedures. How would you feel if someone you cared about was in a car accident and was seriously injured or died because they were denied the right to medical care? This is happening every day in our country when people are denied abortions. Abortion is healthcare.
What someone chooses to do is between them and their doctor--it does not involve anyone else. Medical freedom is important and it should not involve the government. 
Also, if you are so concerned about human life, why don't we look at the real reasons people have abortions? People are struggling to get by in this economy--many can't even afford necessities, and you are concerned about whether someone wants an abortion. We have bigger fish to fry.

Abortion is a deeply personal and complex issue, often framed as a matter of civil rights. However, it’s crucial to recognize that it also involves the rights and well-being of the person carrying the pregnancy. Many people who seek abortions do so under challenging circumstances, including health risks, financial instability, or severe fetal anomalies. Reducing abortion to a matter of convenience oversimplifies the difficult decisions individuals face.

Legal access to abortion is not about devaluing life but about ensuring that people have the freedom to make informed choices about their own bodies. True equality respects the autonomy and agency of all individuals, recognizing that one-size-fits-all solutions don't work in a diverse society. Instead of demonizing those who make these decisions, we should focus on providing comprehensive support systems that empower people to make the best choices for their lives and families.

Abortion is definitely one of the most discussed topics of our time. I understand the need to take responsibility for our actions and I don't think it is morally right to let others pay the consequences of our decisions. However, I do believe there are circumstances where abortion can save the lives of the women who are faced with these tough decisions. In a sense, it is also cruel to subject babies to be born into poverty or be born with disabilities but have no access to the needed support. Aside from the perspective of the child, there are many cases where the woman (and in some cases girls) were forced into pregnancy. I think if we were talking about the right to human life, these victims should also have a right to decide what to do with their bodies. I do agree that it is an issue when babies that are fully developed and aborted in the later trimesters. But while they are still just cells, abortion can be a life saving procedure for many women.

It sounds like you are against abortion because it is preventing children from being born based on the parent's stability. I think they choose abortion to help their future child avoid suffering, especially if it is a painful or quickly-acting disease.

Yeah, this is a realistic answer, I'd say. See, if I had to make an example, I would say the environment in the U.S. is polluted because of corporations; we all know this to be the case. If we took car manufacturers, for instance, one of the biggest corporate polluters... they're producing all of these cars because the American people want to buy them. They're filling the demand. So, on paper, it could be a possibility to stop pollution from these car manufacturers simply by choosing other means of transportation (not choosing to drive a car, for one). However, this answer doesn't seem realistic when you think about how we equate cars with freedom, the layout of many American towns and cities designed to accommodate cars, and how cars have just been so ingrained into our culture for so long now that it seems impossible for us to give them up to stop pollution. That's just one example. Now when you think of other corporate pollutants filling our demands for X or Y product, for the most part you can apply the same instance. No one will stop pollution, because doing so is the toughest responsibility, both on the corporate and the individual level.

Think about equality, and then think about quality of life. Without the option to abort, people are brought into this world by parents who are physically incapable of providing a child with a healthy living environment, food, and other necessary things to keep a person alive let alone happy. This child was born into inequality. Additionally, there are many instances where it is extremely unhealthy for the mother to have a pregnancy, she could die from it, and there are instances where the baby will not make it through the pregnancy, etc. Even for those who believe abortion is murder, abortions are sometimes necessary and should be an option for these people. We should value the mother's life too, right? People should not have the control of a mother's body and whether she chooses to have her baby. If you disagree, then that is your choice and nobody is forcing you to have an abortion if you are ever in the situation where that is an option. Having a child is not just 'inconvenient,' it is a huge, lifelong responsibility that many people are not equipped to handle.

The "environment" is not a tool or a weapon as you claim. The environment is the basis for our economy and is key to sustaining life for all humans. Fundamentally, a concept of one health can be referenced when thinking about why this is an important issue. One health is the idea that human health, animal health and environmental health are all interconnected and work in tandem with each other. If our environment is not in good condition, crops will diminish causing food insecurity problems. If our environment is not doing good, it is not possible for our livestock to thrive. If both livestock and crops are struggling to thrive, the compounding consequences will not provide for an environment suitable for human life. To protect the jobs of farmers, factory workers, grocery store workers and everyone in the line of food processing, we have to protect our environment first.

Each side uses every argument they have as weapons to get power, which makes this statement inherently irrelevant. Also, while the consensus has changed as to how fast the environment is changing, there are many scientific articles that describe the past trends of change, including extinctions (By the way, the number of extinctions that should happen in one lifetime is 1-2, meaning that we are currently in a mass extinction period, similar in size to the extinction of the dinosaurs), so claiming that we don't know how the change is happening is inaccurate....we simply cannot predict the future to the level of precision you would like. What's more, while other countries are contributing to the issue as well, this does not excuse our country from the responsibility to make changes. "Fault" is irrelevant, as is "who did it worse"...our country has a large amount of pollution, and enough to affect the global scale. While jobs will be lost from "traditional" industries, the goal is not to just reduce or get rid of those industries, it is to *replace* them with more sustainable ones. These will have just as many jobs, and even likely reduce our reliance on other countries, since we get a large percentage of our oil from abroad. The oil industry is at the core unsustainable because it is a limited resource. We will need to make the change at some point as oil diminishes, so we should not wait until it becomes dangerously urgent.

I believe that abortion is an act that people should be allowed to make, as it is a personal choice and not something that the government should be able to interfere with. Unless you have been in a position where abortion is a decision you have to consider, it is far too easy to say that those who get abortions do so lightheartedly and out of convenience. It is also hasty to assume that those who support pro-choice do so because they don't care about unborn embryos or fetuses. You can support pro-choice and still care about those in utero, because the topic of abortion is not pro-life or pro-abortion, it is pro-CHOICE. Supporters believe that abortion should not be outlawed by the government, and that women should have control over their bodies.

It's important to understand that environmental issues are generally complicated. While countries like China and India do have high levels of pollution, we must recognize that climate change is a worldwide problem that requires the efforts of everyone across the globe. The scientific consensus on climate change comes from a lot of research and solid evidence, and even though predictions might differ, the general pattern shows that we're facing significant environmental changes that must be dealt with. When it comes to the effects on jobs in traditional energy sectors, it's vital to strike a balance between protecting the environment and maintaining economic stability. Moving towards renewable energy can open up new job opportunities and industries, which could help make up for the job losses in traditional fields.

I understand that people have different opinions on the morality of abortion. Personally, I struggle with the thought of abortion because it can seem like you're taking a potential life away. However, there are many legitimate medical reasons for abortion, and when given a choice between saving the mother or the child, it makes more sense to choose the person who's already living rather than someone who could one day exist. I can also understand your confusion over some of the other reasons people consider abortion, such as the financial cost of raising a child or their potential to have a disability. At the end of the day, it is each person's choice what they do with their own body and life. In my opinion, if someone doesn't want to be pregnant for 9 months, they shouldn't be forced to carry the child.

I understand that you believe abortion to be morally wrong. While I have a very different stance on this issue, I definitely respect your concern for equality. From what I have witnessed, learned, and heard from friends and family who have personal experience with this issue, the financial cost and personal toll of a child, or of pregnancy and birth often reduces a woman's ability to make ends meet and, in many cases, would cause the children she already has to be financially or emotionally neglected (>60% of women receiving abortions already have one or more children). Especially in the case that one of these children has a disability, I feel that protecting the mother and children that have already been born while advocating for more freely available birth control, education, and resources (food stamp-type programs, healthcare for all, low-cost college, etc.) would both lower the rate of abortion and ensure that women and children are able to be well-fed, economically stable, and be contributing members of society throughout their entire lives.

The environmental movement should not be about pointing fingers or assigning blame; it does not matter what country is most responsible for the damage because it must be fixed either way. While many climate related predictions may be off, like the one you refer to, many predictions have been accurate. Climate action is a global, scientific consensus based on extensive research, not a political weapon. It is supported by climate scientists, international organizations, and governments across the political spectrum who recognize the urgency of addressing climate change. While political debates exist about how best to tackle climate change, framing it as solely a tool for political power undermines the real, data-driven concerns about global environmental degradation. It's true that China and India are major polluters, but the argument oversimplifies the issue. Historically, the U.S. and other developed nations have contributed a significant amount of greenhouse gases (GHGs) to the atmosphere during their industrialization. Per capita, the U.S. still ranks among the highest emitters. Addressing climate change requires global cooperation because GHG emissions accumulate over time and don't respect borders. Furthermore, developed nations often outsource their manufacturing to countries like China and India, contributing indirectly to emissions.

I understand that you feel strongly about abortion. As a democrat, however, I can't speak for everyone, I don't want innocent lives to be taken because of irresponsibility. Instead, I want to focus more on initiatives to make sure that people are educated and practicing safe sex in order to avoid unplanned pregnancy. My fear is that if access to abortion is taken away, different, basic health services may be taken away such as birth control and sex-ed. I do not think this is realistic, but overall, I want to emphasize stopping the issue before someone makes the very difficult decision to have an abortion. Finally, I will say that I will always stand for medically necessary abortions that save the mother's life. I think democrats may use this as a "scare tactic" and overemphasize this possibility, however, if any one woman's life is lost, often along with her child, I feel this is a tragedy. It honestly also makes me a little worried to have children one day for fear of not being able to have the rights to my own medical care. Thank you for reading this.

I understand your concerns about call-out culture and how it can sometimes feel like it unfairly punishes individuals without a chance for dialogue or context. It’s important to recognize that while the intent behind calling out harmful behavior is often to promote accountability and justice, the approach can sometimes feel extreme or disproportionate. Many people who participate in call-out culture are motivated by a desire to address real harm and hold people accountable, especially when traditional systems fail to do so. However, I agree that it’s crucial to balance this accountability with fairness and empathy, ensuring that responses allow room for growth, learning, and context. Instead of canceling someone outright, fostering conversations that encourage understanding and positive change might help uphold the values of liberty and human rights that both sides care about deeply.

I understand your frustration. However, there are a few factors I feel that you are not considering. 

Firstly, the vast majority of abortions are performed on groups of cells that may have the potential to become, as you say, "living human beings", but would not be recognised as such by any legitamate medical professional. 

Secondly, abortions are not convienient. They are an extremely invasive medical procedure that can be traumatic for the people involved. 

Additionally, the health of the people involved needs proper consideration. Pregancy is fraut with medical hazards and can be deadly, many people don't want to carry a pregnancy to term due to the dangers involved. 

Making abortion illegal has been proven to cause increased mortality rates for the people forced to carry pregnancies to term. Legalising abortions allows for a dramatic decrease in dangerous, illegal abortions, which will inevitably occur anywhere it is made illegal.

Finally, those who do have late-term abortions are likely doing so because the life of the fetus is already compromised or the health of the parent is at risk, few people are going to go through the pains and struggle of pregancy only to get an  abortion last minute.

I think there's a fundamental disjoint in definition over what constitutes a "living human being" — usually at the time of abortion, the fetus is not considered viable. Also, what is the alternative — that a baby be brought into the world when its parents are not ready to raise a child, or don't have sufficient finances to do so? It would actually then have a pretty miserable childhood in foster care. It's also not just about the child — it's about the rights of the people that have to give birth. I understand your concerns about China and India contributing more than us due to their large population, but you would be surprised to see that the US is actually just as, if not more, responsible than they are. For instance, take the number of barrels of oil used by each country in a day: the US is by far ahead at number 1, while China and India stand at 2 and 3, respectively. You'll see this trend in lots of categories, all of which are contributors to climate change. As one of the world's strongest powers, it's our responsibility to not be reckless in our resource use. We've seen a constant increase in global temperatures over the past century - this is supported by the fact that the average global temperature level has drastically increased since the Industrial Revolution. It's important that we leave behind an Earth that future generations can live peacefully on instead of maintaining the mentality that our changes don't make any difference. We need to be the change.

Reading your statement on Abortion I can see you're passionate about protecting unborn children, and i respect that. In my view Abortion is an extremely complex issue at the intersection of the unborn child, medical ethics, and personal freedom. 
I respect your belief that people are using abortion for their own convenience, I tend to agree, Abortion shouldn't be used as birth control, or mere convenience. I believe Abortion should be used as a last resort only for issues involving rape, incest, and life of the mother. 
The right to abortion is not absolute, but it may be necessary due to socioeconomic issues facing the mother, some folks simply don't want to try to raise a child in poverty, and the difficulties of raising a mentally handicapped child can be extremely difficult. 
We can both agree that abortion is not a replacement for birth control, or an old-fashioned condom. It is an extremely personal medical decision between a woman and her medical provider, and In my view it ought to only be used in limited circumstances in the earliest point of pregnancy possible, and above all we ought to avoid anyone from coercing a woman into aborting a child against her will, or carrying a child to term against her will.

I find it believable that China and India are polluting more than the United States. However, I'd be interested in the source of "lose millions of jobs...in traditional energy industries." Even with a push for cleaner energy, the extraction of oil and gas won't be going away. Could the number of jobs be impacted? Almost definitely. However, I struggle to believe that number will be in the millions. On the flipside, how many future jobs will be negatively impacted by climate change in this century? I don't have numbers on that, but that impact should be considered when going down your line of reasoning. Back to China and India polluting more than the US; even if reductions in our pollutants and emissions are less than theirs, reducing ours would represent a positive change.

I am neither an expert on the environmental movement nor a social justice keyboard warrior, but I am a human who has lived through increasingly hot summers and winters. Ten years ago when I was a child, my area would regularly receive 3+ feet of snow. Now, however, we are lucky to get 6 inches, and that number has been slowly decreasing. It would be wrong of me to ignore that and dismiss it as anything but climate change. Politics aside, this isn't right. Both the right and left have over-politicized the environmental movement by using it as a bargaining chip, but both sides are ignoring the bigger picture: the science, not the incorrect data that you refer to, points towards certain extermination.

In my opinion, while I believe that there is definitely merit to what you say, I think it might be a bit too absolutist and unfair to your opponents. Labeling it as something that "Republicans use" is a blanket statement that lumps all Republicans together. In my experience, Republicans, just like Democrats, are quite diverse in terms of their perspectives on issues and have varying responses to what might be called 'cancel culture.' Next, while I agree that cancel culture is a very positive thing for people who have been marginalized and failed by the justice system, I think that these cases are only part of what the term cancel culture applies to, as you point out in your answers. For this reason, I would probably say I am not really a fan of cancel culture despite me agreeing with you in the cases of genuine exploitation that you describe. I think that cancel culture has in a lot of ways moved away from the original benefits of it when it was being applied during for example the MeToo movement and protests against racial injustice into a tool people use to punish people they don't like for different reasons and try to hold people with any sort of notoriety to an extremely high level of morality. I think there are often cases where people are targeted by 'cancel culture' for (often admittedly bad) statements made a very long time ago when they were much younger, as if we all didn't say and do things that were immoral and that we are now embarrassed about when we were younger. Just my opinion though :)

I would argue that the main reason why China and India pollute more is because they manufacture a lot of the goods that we use. As poorer, less urbanized countries, they don't have as much access to more environmentally friendly manufacturing processes and practices. Large chunks of the working class there are exploited for their cheap labor.

Science can change over the years, especially when we gain more insight as to why something is happening the way it is. Advancements in technology, better funding, and other factors help us create a better and more concise picture.

People in traditional energy industries aren't losing their jobs in massive numbers as of yet. It's true that the coal industry has been hit the hardest so far, but that is due almost purely to market factors, both internal and external. As technology progresses, alternative energy sources like solar and wind are getting exponentially cheaper, to the point where fossil fuels can't compete. The traditional fuel industries will be fine for the next decade or two, as the process of converting the grid and other things (like cars) will take longer than anticipated. During that time, those workers will be trained by their employers to work in these new industries, ones that they are heavily investing in. Companies like Shell and Chevron are already doing this.

I think what you're saying about valuing convenience over human life and about aborting a baby if they find out it will be too expensive or if it has a disability makes sense. What I'm hearing is that you don't believe someone's lifestyle should be considered inherently more valuable than a human life, and that makes perfect sense to me. I think where the conflict arises is that for many people seeking abortions, keeping the pregnancy would lead to a terrible quality of life for both parties. From what I have heard from people who've had abortions, they've done so not because they wanted to maintain a luxurious lifestyle or because they didn't want to spend money on a baby, but because of issues they're facing like addiction, unstable housing, or health problems that would make them unable to adequately care for both themselves and a child. From that perspective, I actually think we both kind of agree--that bringing a baby into the world shouldn't be taken lightly. We just differ on what that should mean in practice; my opinion is that abortion can prevent the suffering of two individuals, both the pregnant person and the hypothetical child.

I understand your concern of human life - but the human life of the women who often face no other choice than abortion must also be considered. From what I understand from your perspective, you believe abortion should not be allowed because unborn children are killed by it for varying reasons such as having a disability or financial issues. Abortion can be a tough choice for someone who is pregnant, and knowing that your child would live with an awful or possibly even life-threatening disability, it may be the kinder thing to do. There is also the issue of being able to support a child, both physically/financially and emotionally. Some parents might not have intended to have a child, and are not in a financial or emotional state to care for a child. There's plenty of horror stories of parents who absolutely should not have had children (from their own children), and while it's debatable whether the amount of those stories would decrease if those parents had the termination of the pregnancy as an option, it's certainly something to consider. There are also inherent risks to pregnancy that some people simply don't want to take. Overall, it's not all about convenience, it's also about kindness: making a hard choice to prevent more suffering later on.

I understand that you are worried about the jobs lost in traditional energy industries, but more environmentally friendly energy solutions will bring in jobs of their own that can offset that. While coastal cities are still not underwater, we have already been able to see the effects of climate change through adverse weather events, and these have hit working-class people the hardest. Hotter summers and colder winders are already affecting American agriculture and outside work like construction. I would rather we put our efforts to try and halt things from getting worse than assume that there's nothing we can do to fix things.

I believe abortions should be a private, medical decision between a woman and her doctor. I don't think abilities of the baby are often considered except in medical emergencies, which should be handled by medical professionals. I think that infringing upon one's personal freedom (of their body) is more harmful and sets more dangerous precedents that the government can control private bodies more than lives that have not yet started. I don't think this is about valuing one life over another. Abortion is a personal decision and I think each woman makes that decision on their own, with the turmoil that goes along with it.

While the issue of abortion is complex, it's crucial to consider the broader context of women's rights and health. Access to abortion is not about disregarding human life but about ensuring that women have the choice to make decisions about their own bodies and futures, especially when this pregnancy was not wanted due to situations that can be out of a woman's control. Restrictions on abortion often lead to endangering women’s lives if the pregnancy is not viable or doing unsafe procedures because the proper healthcare is not accessible. Equality of life means having the right to make choices that are best for one’s own life.

It sounds like you strongly believe that access to abortion is harming innocent lives and that people are making this choice based on convenience. I completely empathize with this perspective and think that your opinion is totally valid. I think we have a lot of alignment in our views- I also believe that barriers to having a child should be reduced so that the high cost of childcare isn't a reason someone has to decide not to have a baby. I do believe that the decision to have a child should be up to each individual. I respect your perspective on why this would be the right choice for you and at the same time I know that there are people for whom being pregnant would be a life-threatening emergency. I think that their lives are important too and they should be able to make the decision whether or not to put their life at risk in those situations. At the end of the day, I do also believe that making abortion illegal is not effective at stopping people from having abortions- instead it makes people turn to much more dangerous ways of obtaining abortions and actually leads to more deaths, which is contrary to the goal of of the pro-life movement.

Although China and India are big polluters, the US has a much longer history of pollution which started around the industrial revolution. In comparison the US has polluted much more overall than China and India, who have just started this pollution boom. While some politicians may be using the environment to get power, it is important to listen to actual scientists who have dedicated their lives to studying climate science. Their goal is not to harm the working class, but instead to ensure a future of a healthy planet for them. Just because jobs may be lost due to an energy transition does not mean that it is not a necessary advancement for our society. Jobs have consistently been lost throughout history due to technological advancements. Just as people who manufactured carriages may have lost their jobs during the rise in the popularity of cars, an energy transition would bring a new wave of jobs and improvements for our air quality and overall health.

I can see that this issue is very important to you, and it’s evident that your viewpoint comes from a deep concern for what you believe are the rights of the unborn and a commitment to protecting vulnerable lives. It's worth noting that those who support abortion rights also often care about human dignity and equality but interpret these principles differently, especially when it comes to reproductive health. I believe that it's okay to disagree. The debate over abortion is incredibly multifaceted, touching on ethical, moral, and deeply personal factors on both sides. Finding common ground isn't easy, but it often starts with recognizing that, despite our different beliefs about when life begins or how to best support those in need, there is often a shared commitment to human dignity and justice. Approaching this issue with open-mindedness and empathy can help us better understand each other's viewpoints, even when we hold differing opinions.

Abortion is definitely one of the bigger issues we face today. As a people, we have a certain moral compass to define right or wrong. The question, is abortion right or wrong, seems to weigh more on the child's right to life over anything else as murder is one of the inherent "wrongs". But in this situation we ought to look at both the expectant mother and the unborn. I personally think government laws should not dictate my personal decisions, like where I choose to go to school, choosing to change my last name, changing my gender and the like. Just like these laws, if they exist, cannot guarantee my health or wellbeing. Abortion is significantly more important than my examples, therefore, even more necessary for the choice to be left in the hands of the expectant. It is no one's place to say what happens to an unborn whom they will not be contributing to raise or support in any way, shape or form.

I absolutely agree that the callous approach taken by many democrats on the topic of abortion is reprehensible. Regardless of where a person stands on the "human" status of a fetus, the loss of even a potential human life is a tragedy and ought to be treated as such. At the same time, I do not believe that the definition of human life is as simple and clear-cut as you put it, nor do I believe that the majority of abortions are simply matters of convenience. If you can accept that the status of human life in the womb is ambiguous to some extent (which is an admittedly significant premise), then it seems that a democratic society ought to be capable of deciding for itself where it is acceptable to draw that line.

Many people who go through this procedure wanted their baby, but their baby will not live and if the baby does, it will be painful and only for a few minutes,"

I would like to think that people can have slightly different viewpoints, yet still share a common interest in the country. I want the best for everyone, and everyone has different experiences that have formed their beliefs. In today's age, society is such that the democratic view is accepted/politically correct. I agree that calling out misogyny, abuse, racism etc. is acceptable. However, where I am, you are called out if you are conservative. People immediately think less of you. Recently, individuals held up a flag during a protest out of respect for the country, and they were ridiculed by the whole student body. I have peers that are adamant republicans that also attend this university, and my other peers look down and belittle those people. People's views are opinions; they are different. Who is deciding now that no matter how liberal of a claim you can make, you will receive no criticism. The result is that I suppress my views, even though I do not believe for them to be extreme in any sense, out of fear of being shunned by my friends and peers. Here, I am the minority in what I believe, which is okay, but it is not okay to see how much everyone openly hates people that share the beliefs I have. If I could wish one thing, it would be for people to be respectful of each other again. I believe it's gone too far.

It is the shared responsibility of all industrially developed countries to practice sustainability by accounting for the economy, the environment, and the social welfare of the people. There are plenty of observational studies that show patterns of which the environment of the earth is changing as industrial development has increased exponentially in recent years, so it is important to acknowledge the role that the United States has played in causing these changes. Even if scientific data did not result in completely accurate predictions, the continuing trends of environmental degradation cannot be ignored. It is not fair that the working class people living in coastal cities are disregarded while their environment degrades around them due to the habits of corporations polluting our planet.

Personally, I believe that in the importance of having children being raised in a physically and emotionally supportive home and that people should not have children if they are unable to provide that. If the parent(s) cannot provide for their child financially, the child will grow up impoverished, with all of the life-long negative outcomes that entails. If the parent(s) cannot support their child due to that child's disability, the child will grow up neglected, with all of the life-long negative outcomes that entails. I understand that you think fetuses are people, but their parent(s) are people too and have the right to be live in a supportive home as well and some cases, to have a child would be to endanger the parent(s). In all of the cases mentioned above, to force the parent(s) to have that child would be to perpetuate the cycles of inequality that already exist. In an ideal world, we would have systems set in place that can support parent(s) through all of this and allow every single child to grow up healthy and happy, but unfortunately, that is not the world we live in and our children deserve better than to be collateral damage while we figure it out.
