Hello, I agree with you that it isn't right to choose abortion only based on the cost. If they truly can't afford to raise the baby, they should put them up for adoption, although the current process is less than favorable. The disability conversation is also very complicated. In the case of a light disability, I agree with you. However, if the result is an extremely poor quality of life for the baby, I think abortion may be preferred. I don't believe most people who choose to have an abortion take this decision lightly. There is a lot of thought that goes into this decision, not all selfish. There are also other reasons for people to choose abortion such as rape, or medical complications. I believe the best solution is prevention. This entails free access to condoms and birth control. Through this, the number of abortions would decrease and there are also other benefits such as lowering the transmission of STIs.

When a fetus is conceived, they are only a matter of cells until the mother is about 5 weeks pregnant. Therefore, it is hard to consider these "unborn living human beings" when they are not yet living on the Earth and are only a cluster of cells. Therefore, this time frame gives mothers an opportunity to have an abortion if there is something gravely wrong with the fetus that may cause the fetus to have chronic health issues or may even cause the mother health issues or death. Making abortion legal would help to prevent a living child with chronic health issues and would also help to prevent the living human mother from a chronic health issue or her death. Therefore, making this illegal would lead to further inequality if a mother and/or her fetus are unable to get an abortion and must die due to a health issue.

Abortion is indeed a deeply significant and contentious issue, and it's important to consider all angles. The central argument for legal access to abortion is that banning it does not eliminate the need for it; rather, it often drives individuals to seek unsafe and potentially dangerous alternatives. This can lead to severe health risks and even fatalities. It’s crucial to address both the legal and health implications of abortion bans and consider the broader impacts on women’s lives and rights. Ultimately, a balanced approach that respects personal autonomy and prioritizes safety and health may be the most effective way to address this complex issue.

Your love and care for women is truly inspiring. We can agree that more government resources should be put toward helping young mothers, women with unexpected pregnancies, and children in struggling families. However, I believe your passion for helping women only extends to some women. Abortion is the process of destroying life -- human life. You may argue that embryos aren't humans and have no rights, but then where is that line? When does an embryo become a human? Heartbeat? Pain tolerance? Viability? Birth? All of these lines are arbitrary. Conception makes scientific, logical, ethical, and reasonable sense. My sisters were once embryos. I was once an embryo. You were once an embryo. A human embryo. We as a society can learn to love them both; pregnant women and their children. Of course, we need to do a lot of work to get assistance in place for pregnant mothers, but we shouldn't abandon children on the way.

However, by similar reasoning, I think it's unfair to the parent of the child to force them to give birth if doing so will harm their livelihood. In our society, the financial and emotional cost of caring for another human how we should be cared for should not be taken for granted. If giving birth would complicate the life of the parent, and consequently give the child a harder life as well, is that worth it so that the child can have a life? Or to reword that, is it better to live a difficult life or to not live one without knowing of the life that could've been lived?

If I understand correctly, your view is that unborn children, humans in the most vulnerable stage of life, are disregarded by pro-choice politicians who prioritize their quality of life over the lives of these children. I certainly agree that is it essential to prioritize the well-being of children, infants, and unborn children so that they can have a fair chance to grow up and live their lives. Any individual who carelessly decides to abort an unborn child without considering the ramifications of this action is doing a disservice to humanity. However, I think that looking at this issue from the perspective of a mother unsuited to raise or birth a child brings up a variety of other problems. I believe that it is not fair to expect that, in every instance of an unwanted pregnancy, the potential mother must allow another human being--her fetus--to essentially occupy and take control of her body and her life. To provide a specific and hopefully uncommon example (since it is a rather bleak one), imagine that a young teenager is sexually assaulted by an older male family member, resulting in a pregnancy. I believe that this is an instance where it is more ethical to provide her with the option of abortion rather than to force her to carry this baby. I know that this is a cherrypicked scenario and that abortion is less justified in many instances, but this is why I believe it is important to, at the very least, provide a pathway for women to have an abortion, even if we only allow it in specific cases.

There is a difference between an unborn child and an embryo. Most abortions happen during the first trimester when the "baby" isn't even a baby. So many different situations could cause an abortion to be the only solution; rape, incest, mother's health, etc. Second trimester abortions are only if medically necessary. If a woman is pregnant and the birth or pregnancy itself could result in her death, why should she keep that "baby"? Why should someone's wife, daughter, sister, mother die just to save a baby that is not even a baby? If the baby is stillborn, why should the mother have to carry it to term? Could you imagine finding out you are pregnant and being so happy only to find out that the baby won't live once it is born? And yet you still have to go through the pain of childbirth just to hold your dead child in your hands. The amount of trauma that could come from a situation like that. I am Pro-Choice, because I don't think I would ever get an abortion, but that doesn't mean I should decide for someone else who's shoes I have never walked in. I am thankful that I have never been put in that situation, but I would hope that I would have more rights than a "baby" who hasn't even breathed air yet. Not to mention our foster systems are overcrowded and, in most cases, terrible situations for the kids. And yet nothing is done about that, on either side of the political pole. We need to take care of the people who are alive already.

I understand where you are coming from however, I personally would have to disagree. Most of the time cancel culture seems to be the opposite of a good justice system. Abortion is the biggest civil rights issue of our time. Abortion is one of those topics that you can use in politics to put both sides in a choke hold. As a woman, being able to get an abortion means more than being able to get an abortion. When Roe V. Wade got overturned it had to do with the bodily autonomy of woman. We no longer had a say over something that men do have a say over. It only takes them that one time to take one right away before it is easy for them to take all of ours rights away. Half of the blood running through me is middle eastern. My father, when I was 10 years old, wanted to take me to Iraq. Obviously the judge ruled against it, but the main reasoning and scare my mother had was that woman were looked at in a different light over there. Woman don't have the right to their bodies or their own minds. They have to obey their male dominants, they cannot show their skin or hair. Some of these girls' fathers would even go to the extreme of killing them or shunning them. You see, being able to have an abortion has more to do with the rights to my body as a woman than it has to do with killing a baby. I cannot speak for all women but I would say most agree with me. Now there are some cases where some women may abuse this and use abortion as birth control, which I don't agree with. But when Roe V. Wade got over turned the next thing after abortion that they wanted to get rid of was... birth control.

Children deserve to be born into families that choose them. To be an unwanted child, resented by the people who should love them the most for the burden they caused, is something I would never wish on someone. And fetuses that are determined to have disabilities in prenatal testing can be prevented from having a lifetime of suffering. Many parents don't feel that they can even care for themselves, much less a disabled child requiring around-the-clock care. Those children deserve more than this. I would also argue that the foster system is not a perfect solution for these issues. Life as a child in the foster care system is unimaginably painful, emotionally, and sometimes physically.

Pro-choice for parents can improve equality because it allows people to make the best choices for themselves and their pregnancies. The ability to choose can allow people to finish degrees, obtain jobs, and contribute to society in ways that they otherwise couldn't if they had not had the choice to have children or not.

I agree that fetuses are extremely vulnerable, but where I disagree is the idea that they are full people, exactly like you and me. The phrase "aborting a baby" can make someone imagine a 2 month year old baby being killed outside the womb for no good reason. However, it is fetuses that haven't been born yet that can be aborted. I personally would prefer a restriction on abortion based on fetal viability, but still, I don't think it's my place to tell other people what to do with their bodies. Abortion would have no place if every baby born could be guaranteed a safe place to live and a loving family, but that is not true in all situations.

I understand your concern and that this is an unfortunate occurrence. However, I still believe that pro-choice advocates for women's rights and allows them to make their own decisions, rather than having them forced upon them. There can be several reasons women seek an abortion. In many cases, women have been raped and, understandably so, may not want to endure nine months of an unplanned pregnancy on top of such a traumatic incident. While I understand the unborn child is innocent, so is the victim, and they were not prepared for such an unexpected situation.
That's why I feel this choice is not easy or only about convenience or financial matters, but is more based on circumstances only the individual can understand.
I also believe in terms of equality, everyone is entitled to their opinions and we should respect that. For instance, one may be pro-life for themselves but still acknowledge that it's not their place to force that belief onto someone else. Everyone should be able to make their own decisions based on what they believe is best for them.

Even though China and India are polluting more than America is, that does not mean that we should not take action to correct our own measures. With a transition from traditional energy industries to renewable sources, many of these workers will be able to find jobs at nuclear facilities, solar facilities, and hydroelectric facilities, all creating more jobs for the future. The shift towards these sources does not end the use of fossil fuels either. Rather than waiting on China and India to do their part, America needs to be the leader and show how transitioning to these sources will better impact the environment and economy.

Yes, China and India are big polluters. However, the U.S. is a major historical and per capita contributor, so global cooperation is necessary, and the U.S. has a responsibility to lead. The mindset that we shouldn't play a role because there are other significant contributors out there won't even start a solution. Also, the transition to clean energy doesn’t mean abandoning workers in traditional industries. Investments in renewable energy can create millions of new jobs, and policies can support retraining for those affected.

It's a similar discussion as to the mass adoption of electric vehicles, and how at the beginning of their implementation there was not a lot of infrastructure to support mass adoption of this new technology and the options that were available were very expensive. But ripping the bandage so to say made it possible to advance the availability to infrastructure that made it easier and more accessible for the public to use EV's in a greater scale with more and more chargers being installed for commercial use instead of tying a charger into your private residence. 
Ripping the bandage in terms of converting our current technologies to reduce the amount of pollution is a large process that will require a lot of resources to get into motion and adopted by the public, but by pushing for that conversion it will be easier to continue it and by establishing resources to do so within the states we might even be able to share with other countries that are trying to do the same and further the development of this conversion!

While the left has not been perfect in their message surrounding addressing the climate crisis, this should not deter us from engaging in aggressive solutions. Firstly, we very much know how the environment has been changing: global temperatures continue to rise, including this summer being the hottest summer on record, while weather phenomena such as hurricanes continue to become more dangerous, just to name a few of the effects climate change has had. However, I do understand some of the places where this student is coming from, though disagree with their approach. For example, I do agree that China and India are polluting more than the United States, but that should not mean that we should not contribute to fighting climate change: we need both a domestic and international approach to solving this crisis. Furthermore, I understand the concern that workers in traditional energy industries might lose their jobs. However, instead of not transitioning to clean energy, we should ensure that the jobs in the green energy sector are going to the places most heavily dependent on traditional energy industries, and provide programs to train working-class people to work in these new industries so that they can have sustainable, healthier jobs. That way, we can bring everyone into a strong economy while fighting climate change, two things that are not mutually exclusive.

hank you for sharing your perspective. It sounds like you’re deeply concerned about protecting what you see as the most vulnerable members of society—the unborn—and you feel strongly that abortion undermines the value of human life. I can see why this would be an emotional and important issue for you. From your point of view, it seems that legalizing abortion disregards the sanctity of life, especially when decisions are based on personal or financial reasons.

I also understand that you feel Democrats are not prioritizing these concerns, which adds to your frustration. I think where we might differ is in how we define and balance personal rights with broader social issues, such as a woman’s autonomy over her own body and health. Many people who support abortion rights do so because they see it as essential to gender equality and personal freedom, especially in cases of medical complications, rape, or severe fetal conditions.

It’s a difficult and sensitive issue for everyone, and I believe both sides care deeply about human rights and equality, even if they approach the problem differently. Do you think there’s any common ground we could explore where both the rights of the unborn and the rights of women are considered?

I don't think it matters what countries are polluting more, but it does matter to respect scientific opinions. These scientists' opinions should be valued but surely not taken as gospel. The process of peer-reviewed studies and experimentation is the reason we have many advancements in our world. I'm not saying the environment is rapidly changing in our generation but their evidence would show that change is occurring. 
Traditional energy also relies heavily on exhaustible resources. Over time, this will not be sustainable. You're right that there is no "cure" to this disease, however if awareness is brought to these issues, then maybe our next generations will not have to suffer for our lack of consideration.

I understand your concerns, especially about the impact of environmental policies on traditional energy workers and the complexity of international pollution. However, I respectfully disagree with the assertion that efforts to address climate change are either unnecessary or primarily political.

While it's true that China and India contribute heavily to global emissions, the U.S. still plays a major role. Historically, the U.S. has been one of the largest emitters, and addressing our own emissions is crucial not only for the environment but for leading by example on the global stage. The idea that what we do won’t make a difference overlooks how international agreements, innovation, and leadership are often shaped by the actions of leading countries.

As for scientific consensus, while predictions sometimes vary in their timelines, the overwhelming majority of climate scientists agree that climate change is happening and that it poses real risks—just look at the increasing frequency of extreme weather events. It's not about isolated predictions but the larger, long-term trends that we can't afford to ignore.

I also agree that it’s important to protect working-class people, especially those in traditional energy sectors. However, many climate policies emphasize a transition to clean energy that can create millions of new jobs. With the right policies, we can manage the transition in a way that supports workers, just as the economy has evolved in other industries over time.

Ultimately, I think the challenge is finding solutions that address the climate crisis while also protecting workers and fostering economic growth—and that’s something we can all work toward.

Ultimately, I think the challenge is finding solutions that address the climate crisis while also protecting workers and fostering economic growth—and that’s something we can all work toward.

I think this is an oversimplified view of abortion. Pregnancy, childbirth, and parenthood are extremely nuanced experiences that vary from person to person. There are a dozen reasons why someone might not want to carry to term. The example that stood out to me was disability of the unborn fetus. There are some cases in which the fetus will not survive outside of the womb and so the person carrying it might not want to continue the pregnancy just for them to ultimately die. Others might decide to continue anyway, but you just don't know what's going on with other people.

It's understandable to worry about jobs in traditional energy sectors, but the science is clear: climate change is real, and human activities are driving it. While China and India are major polluters, the U.S. has been one of the largest historical contributors and it's even worse when we look at the carbon footprint per individual. By leading in green technology, we can create new jobs, drive innovation, and set a global example. Environmental policies aren't about power; they're about securing a sustainable future. The cost of inaction on climate change could be far greater than the transition to a greener economy.

From what I can see, It seems that you're very concerned about saving innocent lives and making sure every human at least has the ability to survive and find their place in the world. I think that's a very noble stance, but I'd like to point out that abortion can be more nuanced. For example, while rare there are instances where a woman gets pregnant and then finds out she has a recessive genetic problem that has a very high chance of being passed on to the baby and would lead to the baby in endless suffering or even infantile death. There are also circumstances where a woman can experience complications during pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy which can prove fatal for the mother long before the baby has a chance to develop and survive outside of the womb. While I do understand your concerns and agree that innocent lives deserve life, I also believe that it would be difficult to justify killing innocent women who did want children and got pregnant but found themselves in situations where it was impossible without killing one or both of the mother and her baby. Maybe we could meet somewhere in the middle and agree on some restrictions while still allowing for circumstances where abortion can be okay?

While some people may indeed be trying to take advantage of the issue for their personal gain, climate change and pollution is a legitimate concern for us and future generations. We can't directly control what China or India are doing, but we can do our part by reducing our environmental footprint. Chances are it'll encourage other nations to follow suit, or will at least give us more time to turn things around. Fortunately the worst case predictions about coastal cities going underwater haven't come to fruition, in part because of ongoing environmental efforts, but we aren't out of the weeds yet and it may still happen in the decades or centuries to come. When it comes to working class people losing jobs, I agree it isn't fair, but as traditional energy jobs close down, new opportunities in green energy jobs will open up. Most people will probably be able to adjust to the new employment market. Some will be left behind, unfortunately, and we should help by building a robust social safety net. In the end, it'll benefit everyone.

While China and India are significant polluters, the U.S. remains one of the largest per capita contributors to greenhouse gas emissions. Tackling climate change is a global responsibility, and U.S. leadership can set a powerful example for other nations. Moreover, predictions about sea level rise and other changes have varied in its timelines. Predictions aren't meant to be definitive in outlining the events of the future, only that they suggest potential consequences of our actions if we continue to engage in inaction. Finally, instead of framing the transition to renewable energy as a job-killer, it can be viewed as an opportunity for growth. Green energy industries, such as solar and wind, have the potential to create new jobs. Jobs such as wind turbine technicians, wind resource analysts, and environmental scientists, are all a few examples of different careers that are/and will be more in demand as we continue to transition to utilizing more sustainable energy sources. If you are needing more convincing in this aspect, all it takes is simple research in new careers that have emerged due to these transitions. However, I can definitely understand the concern for those who are losing jobs. One of which might be, "How are those losing jobs suppose to convert everything they once knew about their career into a new practice?" That's why in response to that, I believe it is importance that we invest in giving these people opportunities, one of which could be free retraining programs. Retraining programs can offer assistance in transitioning to new occupations. Thus ensuring that the economic burden doesn’t fall disproportionately on the working class. Needless to say, instead of being a "cure worse than the disease," fully converting to renewable energy can ignite drive in innovation and economic resilience for future generations.

I understand that you are concerned about women's health and safety, which I do understand. We all need to consider that human life does begin at conception, and the baby also has an inherent right to life. The unborn child is vulnerable and voiceless and deserves to be protected. Just because a women is unable or unwilling to become a parent at this time, does not mean she should terminate the pregnancy. There are other options available like putting the baby up for adoption. There are many people who want a baby who are unable to have one. Having an abortion can often come with it's own long term psychological effect, including feelings of guilt, depression, and anxiety. Carrying the baby to term can help mitigate these effects.

It seems as though your concern is the priority of living people over unborn children's suffering. I can see how the policies Democrats have proposed in the past can appear this way. For me, the issue is that there is no true determination as to when life begins, and whose rights should take priority. I try to think about what kind of environment would be best for a child, especially if it were born with a severe disability to a poor teenage mother with little support. There are a lot of systems that make this an impossible situation and lead to child neglect and abuse, which ultimately lead to early death for the child. In my experience, losing a child in any capacity is life-altering and devastating. I do not believe women make these choices lightly. These systems also affect women of color more strongly than any other demographic. In my opinion, systemic racism plays a huge part in why the freedom to choose - as well as many other freedoms and luxuries not currently easily accessed by the people it affects - is crucial to equality. I feel it would be more productive to talk about fixing the systems that lead to higher abortion rates than getting caught up on the issue of abortion itself.

Regardless of whether or not one can agree to call a fetus a "person", a fetus is, biologically speaking, a member of the human species. That is pretty much irrefutable.

If, then, someone admits that a fetus is a member of the human species, it deserves inalienable human rights. The whole point of the history behind human rights is that you do not have to be human and anything to deserve them. You do not have to be human and a certain race, or gender, or religion to deserve human rights. You have them by virtue of being human.

Any difference that they are able to draw between a fetus and a baby, a child, or an adult is some kind of and: human and born, or human and a certain age, or human and at some developmental stage. If you say that a fetus must be past some certain developmental stage in order to have a right to life, you are saying that the government has the right to set additional requirements that someone has to meet to deserve human rights, which goes against the very definition of human rights.

Any difference that they are able to draw between a fetus and a baby, a child, or an adult is some kind of and: human and born, or human and a certain age, or human and at some developmental stage. If you say that a fetus must be past some certain developmental stage in order to have a right to life, you are saying that the government has the right to set additional requirements that someone has to meet to deserve human rights, which goes against the very definition of human rights.

Historically, protection of the environment has been a cross-party issue. Republican President Richard Nixon famously created the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and many environmental protection movements originated in Evangelical Christian religious revivals of the early 19th century. The politicization of protecting the environment is only a recent development, and unfortunately it has been driven by the American Right, abandoning its promise of conserving and restraint using of resources.

While I understand that the climate crisis might seem to you as distant, foreign or outright not true. Scientists from all countries have reached consensus, not that the coastal cities would be underwater, but that such fossil resources will be exhausted at some point in this century. Those traditional energy industries will be soon gone whether the left or the right gets power. What the left is trying to do is a faster and smoother transition to renewable energy sources. This will alleviate the catastrophic impact of climate change, and also avoid the sudden massive unemployment that will arise when fuels ultimately are exhausted.

I agree with a lot of what they said, such as the fact that banning abortions can lead to women seeking unsafe, illegal methods of abortion. I believe that in serious situations (e.g., rape, incompatibility with life, etc.), the woman should have a chance to decide what to do. She should not be forced to have or not have an abortion because that could cause her serious harm. I am, however, against using abortion as birth control. People argue that women shouldn't have to have babies they don't want, but there are many families who are dying to have a baby (through adoption) and would be glad to take the kid. Sex is not a necessity, and usually, it is a choice. In those cases, I don't believe that there should be an option to hit the delete button for a choice you made. And for those who say abortion is better than foster care, that's a ridiculous argument because that would mean that foster kids should have been aborted. Their lives matter just as much as anybody else's. (I am very passionate about foster care and believe that the right--and the left, for that matter--does not do enough for them, but that's a different discussion.)

I completely understand the concern about women's health and safety. However, from what I have seen, there is science that backs up the humanity of a fetus very early in development. I believe that these fetuses have the same right to life as you and I. If that is the case, the right to life needs to be protected by the government. I don't find the argument of "banning abortions doesn't stop them" to be very convincing because if we were to lift the ban on murder, theft, and tax evasion, we would certainly see an increase in these things. The point of banning something isn't to completely eliminate something that is impossible to eliminate, but it is to reduce it as much as possible for the protection of rights and the function of the society we have built. No one wants the rights of women taken away. There are tens of millions of pro-life women that simply want the life of babies to be protected. I am also in favor of programs to help women and newborns with adoption, a revised foster care system, and more systems in order to protect the life of the millions of fetuses that are very unfortunately killed by abortion in our country.

While it is true that India and China are producing a lot more pollution than America, it doesn't quite show the entire picture. On average, an American produces more pollution than someone from China does. China just so happens to produce more pollution since they have more than triple the population of the US, which of course leads to a higher amount of pollution. Also, from what I've seen and read, we are able to tell how the environment is changing. There's a reason every year we are hitting a new record for the hottest year in recorded history, or why so many weather anomalies are occurring a lot more frequently. It's also why sea levels are rising around the globe. Yes it is true that no city has sunk yet, but scientists did not believe that they would be. Most research found that by at least the year 2050 is when significant sea level rise will cause significant damage to cities. Yes it did not occur now, but it doesn't mean it won't occur in a few decades. I do agree with you that it's not fair that working class people are at risk of losing their jobs due to environmental restrictions. But this doesn't mean that they will be unemployed for the rest of their lives. While many jobs are disappearing in the traditional energy industries, a lot more jobs are appearing in the renewable energy industries. Jobs such as those who install solar panels, or those who assemble electric vehicles. While the cure may hurt some people in the short run, would it make sense to have the rest of the world die because some people didn't want to adjust their way of life.

Thank you for sharing your perspective. I hear your concerns about the economic impact of environmental policies and skepticism about the extent of climate change. It’s understandable to be wary of how major changes might affect people, especially those in traditional energy industries.

However, it’s important to consider that while China and India do contribute significantly to pollution, the U.S. is also a major contributor to global emissions, and addressing climate change requires a global effort. By taking action here, we can set an example and encourage other countries to do the same, as well as advance technology that can help reduce emissions worldwide.

Regarding scientific consensus, it’s true that there have been predictions about climate change that haven’t fully materialized in the expected timeframe, but the broader scientific agreement remains that the climate is changing, largely due to human activities. Even if some predictions seem off, the evidence of rising temperatures, extreme weather, and other effects is strong.

In terms of job loss, I completely agree that it’s not fair for working-class people to bear the brunt of these changes. That’s why many propose policies that include job training and support for workers transitioning from traditional energy to renewable energy sectors, which could create new jobs and industries.

It’s a complex issue, and I appreciate you bringing up these important concerns. It’s vital that any solution balances environmental responsibility with economic fairness for everyone involved.

It seems to me that you believe that the environmental movement is essentially pointless, and is mostly used by left candidates as a way to get more voters by naive Americans, and that it is not worth the job losses when other countries are far worse and do nothing to help. In my opinion and because of scientific studies, I believe that the Earth is becoming exponentially more polluted with greenhouse gases over time at a pace that nature cannot evolve quickly enough with, and that this will ultimately lead to a heating point of the Earth from which we cannot recover. Therefore, it is vital that we do anything we can, even if others are not, in order to protect our planet and the people in it, especially those in coastal areas who are already experiencing floods, hurricanes, wildfires, etc. at a rapidly increasing pace. Pollution of the oceans and air is an entirely separate issues as well, and should also be addressed. In the long term, I believe that the shift (not necessarily loss) in jobs from traditional energy source industries to more sustainable energy sources is hardly a hurdle, and that it's the most simple way that we can reduce humanity's carbon footprint. It just so happens that those who hold this belief also hold other leftist beliefs.

It sounds to me that you oppose abortion because you feel it fails to take into account the "life" of the fetus. However, I wonder why you prioritize the fetus over the mother. In my opinion, I think that there are times when it is important to prioritize the life of the mother over the life of the fetus. For example, if giving birth would present serious health risk to the mother, then should she still be obligated to deliver? Also, while I agree that protecting human life is important, I don't necessarily think that a fetus constitutes a human life. "Fetus" is notably not interchangeable with "baby" because there is a bit of difference between a clump of cells and a human being.

Thank you for your perspective. I agree that cancel culture is a way for marginalized groups to hold powerful individuals accountable, especially in addressing issues like exploitation, misogyny, abuse, and racism. It’s true that calling out harmful behaviors can play an important role in creating a more just and equitable society. However, I do believe that cancel culture is not exclusively used by Republicans. Both parties have used it in different contexts. When not used correctly, it becomes harmful and counterproductive. reducing complex issues to simplistic judgments and shutting down meaningful discussion. I believe there’s a difference between holding people accountable and using call-outs in a way that feels more punitive or dismissive, which can sometimes feel childish or unfair.

From my perspective, you seem to be someone who deeply cares about life and making sure that unborn children aren't at the mercy of other people. I think that istotally valid perspective and I understand where you're coming from. I used to have a fairly similar perspective, and I didn't understand why people were so intent on killing babies. However, something that helped flip my viewpoint was thinking about a pregnancy's effect on the mother of a child, as well as the child. I think that most people who have an abortion go through a really tough internal debate about what they should do, and it's not something that is taken lightly. It may be the case where someone gets pregnant, and they might not be equipped to be a parent. Maybe they got pregnant really young, or they suffered an injury. Maybe they have some sort of medical condition that could endanger the baby's life or their own. I understand that you are focused on abortion as the willfull termination of life. While I do not believe that a recently conceived fetus is alive, I am not going to argue about that point. I think that is a religious and philosophical debate that serves no purpose. I would urge you to think about the mothers of the world, whose life could be upended or destroyed by an unwanted pregnancy. They deserve to live their lives too, and sometimes its not the right situation for a baby to be brought into this world. I believe that allowing people to choose can help mothers bring children into this world where they can be properly cared for, fed, educated, and loved, without sacrificing the health of the mother.

To me, this brings up an interesting conversation: how can the government better support communities who cannot afford to take care of their child, resulting in an abortion? I believe abortion should be legal, but I also believe the government should insure no one feels forced to have an abortion because of their financial situation.

I completely agree that abortion is the biggest civil rights issue of our time: An attack on the right to life against the unborn. Just because something may happen regardless of its legality doesn't mean it should be legalized. Laws are meant to protect the vulnerable, and that includes the unborn. Every human life, regardless of age or stage, has intrinsic value and deserves protection. We should respect the bodies and "choices" of those in the womb as well. Laws should be in place to ensure that all life is valued, not to promote actions that harm both the unborn and society at large.

I think that someone deciding to not have a baby because they cannot afford to support a child is actually not only valuing themselves, but that unborn human being as well. There are points I resonate/agree with- the first being the disregard for environmental standards by other Superpowers like India and China- this was the logic used to leave the Paris Climate Agreement- however the environment supercedes political discourse. To put it simply, America doesn't have a left political party anymore. The democrats are the same brand of Neo-conservative that republicans were before Trump. Climate Change discourse isn't a leftist tool for political control- its a social and humanitarian issue. We can't interfere with China/India's environmental standards but we can impose sanctions- just because they don't follow the rules doesn't mean we shouldn't- that's anarchy. I also understand the point about job loss- however as resources like fossil fuels deplete- those jobs will end up disappearing anyway. The problems of climate change aren't from leftist echo-chambers, they're apparent in all facets of life- whether it be hyperinflated prices of groceries because of food shortages, unpredictable monsoon seasons in South Asia, or even the amount of mercury you find in every fish. Microplastics are being consumed regardless of political party. And there isn't even a cure. Just mild alleviation of disease.

I totally understand the feeling that climate change is being weaponized in order to win votes. Centering environmental concerns while working people can't afford groceries doesn't exactly sound just does it? My thought here is that, from my understanding, it is the working people trying to get groceries that are being crushed by a lot of the environmental change we are seeing. I live in wildfire country and my home insurance went up so much my family couldn't afford it anymore and lots of other insurers stopped even offering policies to my county. That's a political failure. Lots of working class people are being affected by events like the Texas freeze and the Houston floods, and I do agree, instead of weaponizing fearmongering we need to come together and support a future that prioritizes placing public interest first. However, I think that means we invest in green energy, especially in areas that have been hit by the loss of industry and the dying coal industry. Lots of my family are from coal districts in PA. We know that coal is never coming back, but that doesn't mean we just abandon those people and towns. I think we can agree more needs to be done for the working class, but I just see protecting them from climate change and providing green energy jobs as an opportunity to do that rather than a way to hurt them.

I think the statement oversimplifies the concept of cancel culture by framing it as something only Republicans criticize, when in reality, concerns about cancel culture come from people across the political spectrum. While it's important for marginalized groups to speak up against injustice, I believe cancel culture can sometimes lead to unintended consequences, like stifling open discussion and promoting a fear of making mistakes, even minor ones. There’s also the issue of due process--people can be punished or ostracized before any proper investigation or conversation takes place. Instead of fostering a healthier society, cancel culture can sometimes shut down productive dialogue, harden divisions, and lead to a more punitive environment where people are afraid to express differing opinions, even if they do so respectfully. It’s crucial to strike a balance between calling out harmful behavior and allowing space for growth, dialogue, and learning.

When it comes to energy, I do think renewable sources are the future, but I think the rate at which they are being pushed is too fast for how efficient they are at the moment.

In my opinion, cancel culture gives no room for growth or for mistakes to be made. Everyone is human, and the world is changing everyday. With this change comes more politically correct ways to handle yourself, and although that change will occur, change still takes time. If you immediately try to ruin another person's livelihood because of something said, you are giving that person no room to improve themselves as a person, which is something I personally don't believe in. Second chances aren't required, but imagine if you were never given a second chance on anything.

I think what you are saying is that 'cancel culture' is not a bad thing because it can be used to help limit hateful behaviors. Is that accurate? I believe that 'cancel culture', or censorship in some cases, cuts into the First Amendment which is one of the founding principles of our Constitution. In your first sentence, it also sounds like you are implying that Republicans are the main people affected by this, but there have been many cases of Democrats being canceled, or censored, as well. I think sometimes 'cancel culture' can affect people wrongfully on any side of the political spectrum. I believe being more open-minded about topics like this will be a step in the right direction for having more civil conversations.

It doesn't matter who is polluting the most or who started it. The point is that the USA is still one of the biggest polluters in the world and we should have the best interest of humanity in mind. Additionally, we have already seen the effects of climate change in the massive, large-scale environmental disasters of the last five years.

You are right that China and India are polluting way more than America. However, I think if American political leaders prioritize environmentalism for their country, they also prioritize it in international negotiations. The US backed out of the Paris climate agreement. This gave other countries an excuse to ignore this and other international climate agreements.

I don't think the "scientific consensus" was ever that coastal cities would be underwater now, but that they will be in a few decades. Last, the fossil fuel industry does not provide millions of jobs. Renewables provide jobs as well, it's a fast-growing industry, and it's a cheaper source of energy.

Although pro-choice advocates support people's ability to make very personal decisions about their own bodies and circumstances, I understand your concern about the dignity of life. People's ability to make the best decisions for themselves is made possible by ensuring safe and legal access to abortions, which can be vital in intricate and challenging circumstances. Encouraging this option is about preserving equality and individual freedom to choose what is best for their own situation.
